svcproc.title: DIAGNOSIS AND TROUBLESHOOTING
svcproc.para:
Table 2
is the Symptom List. This list allows the mechanic to enter the Troubleshooting tables without running the Operational Test, IF he knows the symptom.
Tables 3 thru 14 are the Troubleshooting Procedures for each symptom in tables 1 and 2.

Three types of faults are possible in the lift axle system: electrical, air, and mechanical. While troubleshooting an electrical problem, unless instructed otherwise, refer to FIGURES 42 through 47. When troubleshooting an air system problem, unless instructed otherwise, refer to FIGURE 10 or FIGURE 19. When troubleshooting a mechanical problem, refer to the table of contents to locate the section of the manual covering the axle configuration being tested.

para.emph: Symptom: Lift Axle System Operates with Key OFF

entry.para: This symptom indicates that voltage is present on the Switched 12 Vdc line (SW 12 VDC) even though the key is off and the lift axle system has not been enabled.
Verify that ignition key is OFF.
Locate and repair the short circuit to +12 VDC Battery voltage on the SW 12 VDC line (pin 8 of the AXLE ENABLE switch connector).

para.emph: Symptom: Lift Axle Cannot be Raised or Does Not Raise Automatically with Key OFF

entry.para: This symptom indicates that an electrical, mechanical or air problem exists that keeps one or all of the lift axles from being raised. This symptom could be the result of any of the following conditions:

item.para: mechanical interference is preventing the lift axle from raising completely.
voltage is present on the Switched 12 Vdc control line to a lift axle solenoid even though the key is off and the lift axle system has not been enabled.
an air leak in the supply lines between the truck reservoir and the axle mounted air tanks
a leak in the air system contained on the lowered lift axle
a defective solenoid on the lowered lift axle.

note.para: Always check connectors for damage and pushed-out terminals.

item.para: Verify that the truck air system is fully charged.
Verify that ignition key is OFF.

entry.para: Lift axle assemblies (single lift axle systems and multiple lift axle systems)
All lift axles should be in the raised position when the key is OFF.
If only one lift axle on a multiple lift axle truck is affected, proceed to the next step.
On single lift axle trucks; check for an air leak in the air supply lines from the truck reservoir to the tanks mounted on the lift axles. If no leak is found, proceed to the next step.
If none of the lift axles on a multiple lift axle truck will raise; locate and repair the leak in the air supply lines from the truck reservoir to the tanks mounted on the lift axles.
On affected axle, inspect for interference with chassis drive line or chassis components.
The lifting path of the axle must be free of interference.
If no interference is found, proceed to the next step.
If interference is found, make any necessary repairs to remove the interference.
On the affected axle, check voltage between pin A of the solenoid connector and ground.
0 Volts dc
If the voltage is 0 Volts dc, proceed to the next step.
If 12 ±1.5 Volts is present, the circuit connected to pin A of the solenoid connector is shorted to a voltage source and is energizing the solenoid. Locate and repair the short.
Axle mounted air system of affected axle.
No leaks
If a single lift axle will not raise; check the following components in the air system for that axle to locate and repair the air leak.

item.para: axle mounted tank
relay valve for axle brakes
PPV
air solenoid
lift bags
QRVs for lift bags
all air lines connected to the listed components.

entry.para: If no leaks are found, replace the axle mounted solenoid. (Solenoid is stuck.)

para.emph: Symptom: Lift Axle System Enabled Whenever Key is ON (AXLE ENABLE Indicator Always Lit When Key is ON)

entry.para: This symptom indicates that voltage is present on the Switched 12 Vdc line (SW 12 VDC) whenever the key is on even though the lift axle system has not been enabled. This symptom could be the result of any of the following conditions:

item.para: a stuck or shorted AXLE ENABLE switch
a short to a voltage source anywhere on the SW 12 VDC line (pin 8 of the AXLE ENABLE switch connector)

entry.para: Locate and repair the short circuit.

para.emph: Symptom: Lift Axle System Cannot be Enabled

entry.para: This symptom indicates that a problem exists in the lift axle electrical circuit. This symptom could be the result of any of the following conditions:

item.para: fuse in 12 Vdc IGN line is open (possible short to ground on the line)
defective component (AXLE ENABLE switch, Axle Enable relay, Reverse Lift relay)
open 12 VDC IGN line in lift axle circuit
open ground line in lift axle circuit
12 Vdc present on REVERSE sensing line when not in REVERSE (Self-Steer axles only)

note.para: Always check connectors for damage and pushed-out terminals.

item.para: Verify that ignition key is OFF.

entry.para: fuse for lift axle system
fuse blown, open
If fuse is blown, proceed to next step.
If fuse is ok, proceed to step 6.
Remove fuse. Measure resistance to chassis ground at connector (1019), pin A.
>1 Ohm
If resistance is >1 Ohm, proceed to next step.
If resistance is <1 Ohm, locate and repair the short circuit to ground on the 12 VDC IGN line before replacing fuse.

item.para: AXLE ENABLE switch
Axle Enable relay
wiring

entry.para: While measuring resistance to ground at (1019) pin A, press AND HOLD the AXLE ENABLE switch.
>1 Ohm
If resistance is >1 Ohm, release the AXLE ENABLE switch and proceed to next step.
If resistance is <1 Ohm, locate and repair the short circuit to ground on the SW 12 VDC line before replacing fuse.

item.para: AXLE ENABLE switch
Axle Enable relay
Reverse Lift relay (Self-Steer axles only)
all Axle UP/DN switches
wiring

entry.para: Set AXLE 1 UP/DN switch to DOWN.
While measuring resistance to ground at (1019) pin A, press AND HOLD the AXLE ENABLE switch.
>1 Ohm
If resistance is >1 Ohm, release the AXLE ENABLE switch, set AXLE 1 UP/DN switch to UP and proceed to next step.
If resistance is <1 Ohm, locate and repair the short circuit to ground on the 12 VDC line from the AXLE 1 UP/DN switch to the solenoid mounted on lift axle 1, before replacing the fuse.

item.para: AXLE 1 UP/DN switch
Axle 1 solenoid
wiring

entry.para: If applicable, repeat the previous step for axles 2 and 3, while checking the related circuits.
If resistance is >1 Ohm for all axles, release the AXLE ENABLE switch, verify all AXLE UP/DN switches are set to UP, and replace the fuse. Fuse failure was not due to a short to ground.

If resistance is <1 Ohm, locate and repair the short circuit to ground on the 12 VDC line from the AXLE UP/DN switch to the solenoid of the lift axle being tested. After making repairs replace the fuse.
Measure resistance to chassis ground at the following connector points: (1019) pin C, (1020) pin 10, and (1021) pin 2.
<1 Ohm
If resistance is <1 Ohm, proceed to the next step.
If resistance is >1 Ohm, locate and repair the open in the ground circuit.

item.para: Verify that all AXLE UP/DN switches are set to UP.
Turn on the ignition key.

entry.para: Check voltage between the following connector points and ground: (1019) pins A and B, (1020) pin 2B, and (1021) pin 1.
12 ±1.5 Volts
If voltage is present, proceed to the next step.
If voltage is missing at any point, locate and repair the open circuit between the fuse and the point of the missing voltage.
Set the AXLE 1 UP/DN switch to DOWN. Monitor the indicators on the AXLE ENABLE switch and the AXLE 1 UP/DN switch, while pressing the AXLE ENABLE switch several times.
Indicators on the AXLE ENABLE switch and the AXLE 1 UP/DN switch
If neither indicator lights,

item.para: (FIXED AXLES ONLY) - Isolate and repair the open circuit between (1020) pin 2B and (1020) pin 8. This includes the contacts of the AXLE ENABLE switch.
(SELF-STEER AXLES ONLY) - Proceed to step 11.

entry.para: If the indicator on the AXLE 1 UP/DN switch lights and stays lit after the AXLE ENABLE switch is pressed the first time, proceed to step 10.
If both indicators light ONLY while the AXLE ENABLE switch is depressed, proceed to the next step.
Turn the ignition key off and measure the resistance between pins 4 and 5 of connector (1021)
<1 Ohm
If resistance is <1 Ohm, replace the AXLE ENABLE relay.
If resistance is >1 Ohm, repair the open circuit between pins 4 and 5 of connector (1021)
Verify that the ignition key is on. Monitor the indicator on the AXLE ENABLE switch while momentarily jumpering pin 2B to pin 8 on the switch connector (1020).
Indicator must light when pins are jumpered.
If indicator does not light, replace AXLE ENABLE switch.
If indicator does light, isolate and repair the open circuit between (1020) pin 8 and (1022) pin 2B.
(SELF-STEER AXLES ONLY) - Measure the voltage from (1916) pin 5 to ground.
0 Volts
If the voltage is 0 Volts, isolate and repair the open circuit between (1020) pin 2B and (1020) pin 8. This includes the contacts of the AXLE ENABLE switch and the Lift Axle Reverse Relay.

If 12 ±1.5 Volts is present, locate and remove the voltage source on the Reverse sensing line between (1916) pin 5 and (9700) pin D7. (This line should only have 12 Vdc on it when the transmission is in Reverse.)

para.emph: Symptom: Lift Axle 1 System Not Operating Correctly (Axle Does Not Drop or DOWN Indicator Does Not Light)

note.para:
Refer to Table 6
if the indicator on the AXLE ENABLE switch does not light.

entry.para: This symptom indicates either a problem in the lift axle 1 electrical circuit or a problem in the lift axle 1 air system. This symptom could be the result of any of the following conditions:

item.para: defective component (AXLE 1 UP/DOWN switch or Lift Axle 1 solenoid)
open 12 VDC IGN line in Lift Axle 1 circuit
open ground line in Lift Axle 1 circuit
problem in the Lift Axle 1 air system.

note.para: Always check connectors for damage and pushed-out terminals.

item.para: Verify that ignition key is ON.
Lift Axle system must be enabled (AXLE ENABLE indicator must be lit).
Set the AXLE 1 UP/DOWN switch to the DOWN position.

entry.para: The DOWN indicator on the AXLE UP/DOWN switch and the lift axle assembly.
The DOWN indicator must light, and the lift axle being tested must lower.
If the indicator is not lit, but the axle lowered properly, proceed to the next step.
If the indicator is not lit, and the axle did not lower, proceed to step 4.
If the indicator is lit, but the axle did not lower properly, proceed to step 5.
Measure voltage between pin 8 of the AXLE UP/DN switch connector and chassis ground.
12 ±1.5 Volts
If the voltage is present, proceed to the next step.
If the voltage is not present, repair the open circuit between pins 1 and 8 of the AXLE UP/DOWN switch connector.
Measure voltage between pin 10 of the AXLE UP/DOWN switch connector and chassis ground.
0 Volts
If the voltage is 0 Volts, replace the AXLE UP/DOWN switch (the indicator is open).
If 12 ±1.5 Volts is present, repair the open circuit between pin 10 of the AXLE UP/DOWN switch connector and connector (1019) pin C.
Measure voltage between pin 2B of the AXLE UP/DOWN switch connector and chassis ground.
12 ±1.5 Volts

item.para: (FIXED AXLES ONLY) - Repair the open circuit between pin 2B of the AXLE UP/DOWN switch connector and connector (1021) pin 4.
(SELF-STEER AXLES ONLY - Repair the open circuit between pin 2B of the AXLE UP/DOWN switch connector and connector (1916) pin 3.

entry.para: If the voltage is present, replace the AXLE UP/DOWN switch (the switch is open).
Measure voltage between pin A of the lift axle solenoid connector, and chassis ground.
12 ±1.5 Volts
If the voltage is not present, repair the open circuit between pin 1 of the AXLE UP/DOWN switch connector and pin A of the lift axle solenoid connector.
If the voltage is present, proceed to the next step.
Measure voltage between pin B of the lift axle solenoid connector, and chassis ground.
0 Volts
If 12 ±1.5 Volts is present, repair the open circuit between pin B of the solenoid connector and chassis ground [pin B to (9700) pin B9, or (9700) pin B9 to chassis ground].
If the voltage is 0 Volts, the solenoid is defective, replace the defective solenoid.

para.emph: Symptom: Pressure Regulator and/or Gauge not Operating Correctly

entry.para: This symptom indicates either a problem in the lift axle pressure regulator or pressure gauge. This symptom could be the result of any of the following conditions:

item.para: defective lift axle pressure regulator,
defective lift axle pressure gauge,
blockage or leak in the Lift Axle air system.
Install an in-line air pressure gauge into the air system for the load bags of the lift axle being tested.
Verify that ignition key is ON.
Verify that air system is up to full pressure, and that the lift axle is in the up position.
Enable the lift axle system and lower the axle being tested.

entry.para: While monitoring the in-line air gauge, adjust the pressure regulator for the axle being tested.
Set the regulator to achieve the following pressure, as indicated on the in-line gauge.

item.para: Fixed axles - 15 psi
Self-Steering axles - 31 psi

entry.para: If the pressure cannot be achieved, check the system for leaks. If no leaks are found, replace the pressure regulator.
If the pressure is achieved, but the mounted gauge does not read within several psi of the in-line gauge, replace the mounted gauge.

para.emph: Symptom: Self-Steering Lift Axles Do Not Automatically Lift When REVERSE is Selected (Other Functions are Normal)

entry.para: This symptom indicates a problem in the lift axle reverse relay electrical circuit. This symptom could be the result of any of the following conditions:

item.para: no 12 Vdc from the Transmission/Backup Light circuit.
open REVERSE control line in Reverse Relay circuit
open ground line in Reverse Relay circuit
defective component (LIFT AXLE REVERSE RELAY)

note.para: Always check connectors for damage and pushed-out terminals.

item.para: Verify that ignition key is ON.
Transmission must be placed in REVERSE while making voltage measurements.

entry.para: Verify transmission is in REVERSE.
Measure voltage between connector (1917) pin A, and chassis ground.
12 ±1.5 Volts
If the voltage is not present, proceed to the next step.
If the voltage is present, proceed to step 3.
Verify transmission is in REVERSE.
Measure voltage between connector (9700) pin D7, and chassis ground.
12 ±1.5 Volts
If the voltage is present, repair the open circuit between (9700) pin D7 and (1917) pin A, including connectors (1027) and (9761).
If the voltage is not present, no 12 Vdc is being produced by the Reverse/Backup Light circuit. (Refer to GROUP 08 of the Master Service Manual).
Verify transmission is in REVERSE.
Measure voltage between connector (1916) pin 5, and chassis ground.
12 ±1.5 Volts
If the voltage is present, proceed to the next step.
If the voltage is not present, repair the open circuit between (1916) pin 5 and (1917) pin A.
Verify transmission is in REVERSE.
Measure voltage between connector (1916) pin 2, and chassis ground.
12 ±1.5 Volts
If the voltage is present, repair the open circuit between (1916) pin 2 and (1019) pin C.
If the voltage is not present, replace the defective Lift Axle Relay.

para.emph: Symptom: Second Lift Axle Pressure Gauge Not Working Correctly

entry.para: This symptom indicates a problem isolated to the air system for the second gauge of the lift axle being tested.
Isolate the problem to a defective gauge or blocked air line.

para.emph: Symptom: Lift Axle Lowers Whenever Lift Axle System is Enabled

entry.para: This symptom indicates that the Switched 12 Vdc (SW 12 VDC) is present at the solenoid of the affected lift axle whenever the lift axle system has been enabled. This symptom could be the result of any of the following conditions:

item.para: a stuck or shorted LIFT AXLE UP/DOWN switch (pin 1 to pin 2B of the switch connector)
a short to the SW 12 VDC voltage source anywhere on line from pin 1 of the LIFT AXLE UP/DOWN switch connector to pin A of the lift axle solenoid connector

entry.para: Locate and repair the short circuit.
Axle not tracking properly
Front alignment collars not fastened properly (fixed lift axles only)
Align axle assembly and secure the alignment collars using the correct mounting hardware and torque values. Refer to ADJUSTMENTS .
Axle is misaligned (fixed lift axles only)
Align axle assembly and secure the alignment collars using the correct mounting hardware and torque values. Refer to ADJUSTMENTS .
Arm bushings worn out
Replace worn bushings.
Broken steering component (self-steering axles only).
Locate and repair broken steering component. Refer to GROUP 02 in the Master Service Manual.
Insufficient air pressure to system.
Refer to GROUP 04 in the Master Service Manual.
Defective truck compressor
Check air compressor.
Refer to GROUP 04 in the Master Service Manual.
Pressure protection valve
Replace pressure protection valve.
Refer to GROUP 04 in the Master Service Manual.
Pusher axle steers in opposite direction of truck. (Self-steering axles only)
Improper caster setting. Caster is preset and not adjustable. Check for broken component or worn bushings.
Replace worn bushings.
Repair/replace broken component.
Lift axle has vertical hop
Load bag air pressure is set too low.
Increase air pressure in load bags.
